Increase in Section 179 Expensing: The dollar limitation for expensing under the Internal Revenue Code is permanently increased to $100,000, with a threshold for reduction set at $500,000. Inflation adjustments are also included in the amendment. The dollar limitation for expensing under the Internal Revenue Code is increased by a cost-of-living adjustment for taxable years after 2004. Additionally, the phaseout amount is increased for taxable years after 2005. The dollar limitation for expensing is adjusted for inflation for taxable years after 2004, with rounding rules applied. The amendments made by this subsection apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2004. Special rules for the work opportunity credit are outlined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this subsection apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2004. Special rules for the work opportunity credit are outlined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This section and section 39 shall be applied separately with respect to such credit. In applying paragraph (1) to such credit, subparagraph (A) shall not apply, and the limitation under paragraph (1) shall be reduced by the credit allowed under subsection (a) for the taxable year. The term 'work opportunity credit' refers to the credit allowable under subsection (a) by reason of section 51(a). Special rules for the welfare-to-work credit include separate application of sections 51 and 39, with certain limitations not applying. The paragraph discusses the reduction of the credit allowed under subsection (a) for the taxable year, excluding the welfare-to-work credit or the research credit. Special rules for the research credit are also outlined, including separate application of sections 51 and 39. The text discusses the reduction of the credit allowed under subsection (a) for the taxable year, excluding the research credit. Special rules for the research credit are outlined in the paragraph. The amendments made by this subsection expand the types of credits eligible for certain tax benefits, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2004. SEC. 2. STANDARD HOME OFFICE DEDUCTION. The amendment adds a standard home office deduction of at least $2,500 for certain uses of a dwelling unit as a residence. This deduction is not subject to limitations on deductions. The effective date for the amendments made by this section is for taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act, except as provided in paragraph (7). SEC. 3. MINIMUM WAGE PROVISIONS. Increase in tip income and minimum wage amendments are proposed in the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. Tip income cash wage should be at least $3.25 an hour starting October 1, 2005. Small employers with ten or more employees are exempt from certain minimum wage requirements, with a phased increase in place. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 proposes amendments to increase tip income and minimum wage. The minimum wage should be at least $5.15 an hour until September 30, 2005, then increase to $5.50 an hour from October 1, 2005. The minimum wage further increases to $6.00 an hour from October 1, 2006, and to $6.50 an hour from October 1, 2007. The amendment is effective starting October 1, 2005. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to increase the exemption for annual gross volume of sales made by an enterprise. The minimum threshold is set at $500,000 until September 30, 2005, then increases to $650,000 from October 1, 2005, $800,000 from October 1, 2006, and $1,000,000 from October 1, 2007. The Social Security Act is amended to include provisions for individuals without eligible spouses and those with eligible spouses regarding minimum wage rates and earned income exclusions. The Social Security Act is amended to include provisions for minimum wage rates and earned income exclusions for individuals with eligible spouses. The amendments will take effect on October 1, 2005, and apply to benefits for months starting on or after that date.
